I eat at Jack's; for fast food burgers, they are head and shoulders above the Clown-Shoe wearing Golden Arch Company and their drive thru is usually faster and less annoying than the Clown-Shoe company. Are they woke? No. Do they know what it is? Perhaps; but I think they're too busy perfecting that fried chicken dinner (it's number 14 on the menu, and best with coleslaw and green beans).

I drink Cheerwine and Sundrop sodas because they are unique and most people outside of the Carolinas see them when I bring some to a party, but they do support local high-school football teams in the Carolinas, so there's that. Are they woke though? No. Do they know what it is? Maybe, but I kind of doubt it.

I use Bic razors and Bic pens because they spend all of their energy making excellent razors and excellent ball-point pens for a reasonable price; and they don't bother telling me what I need to be to use their product. Are they woke? No, they don't have time for that shit.

I have multiple cars of multiple brands, but I've always been a Mopar fan; Dodge as a company, have you noticed? You can't be "Woke" and make a car called the "DEMON" that comes from the factory with 808 horsepower or a crate engine called the "HELLEPHANT" that comes from the factory with 1007 horsepower. The new consensus around the campfire is that all new modern cars will be all electric, and that they will all be equipped with bio-degradable wiring harnesses that last about 10 years and then need complete rewiring, and that you won't own it anyway. Through all of that, Dodge has basically been saying, "Yeah, about that, we didn't get that memo..." Are they woke? Haha, they laugh at it.

My cars ride on Kumho; they're owned and mostly made in South Korea and South Korea have been our friends through this whole debacle that has been what? the past 3, maybe 4 presidents? yeah, Kumho's are the best value for money right now. They ride better than BadYear, they last longer than Michelin, and they're less expensive than Pirelli's. Are they woke? I doubt it; I don't think there's a Korean word for "woke"; so I suspect we're safe on that one, at least for now.

I shop at Ingle's markets for groceries because they were the company that gave me my first job as a teenager and taught me a thing or two about "quality". Are they woke? Probably not; they're still listening to Hank Williams Sr., and any elevator music made after 1991 is "Risque" for them to play as overhead music, in their stores, so, no, I really doubt it.

I bank at a small local bank that has a few branches and is big enough to provide real financial backing, but is small enough to actually give two shits about me; they are also the sort of company to advertise in the local high-school football program.

I get my Auto Insurance from a big company that DOESN'T ADVERTISE. Auto-Owners Insurance Company, was once featured on a Clark Howard Investigative News special on ACTUAL responsiveness among claim holders; and was rated as FIRST and BEST; BEHIND State Farm which placed admittedly a close second, and then Farmers, then Allstate, then Liberty Mutual- The companies that advertised the most got nearly the worst rating when it came to claim payouts. Geico ranked near the bottom, only beating Cotton States Insurance (which has recently been bought up by one of the big boys). So Geico, yeah, 15 minutes could save you 15%, until you have an accident... Is Auto-Owner's "Woke"? I don't get that impression walking into their offices; my agent asks me how's my day been, and so on, and I get the impression they do that with everybody; so take that for whatever it may be worth.

Forget a list of companies to avoid, let's start a list of companies to seek out. Regardless of which side of the "fence" you're on, it's nice to be able to just buy a product for the virtues of the product alone; and isn't that we as Americans used to do anyway?

First of all what this boils down to is companies reacting and adapting in whatever way they think is in the best interest of their shareholders, which is the sole purpose of any corporation. It's basically capitalism doing what capitalism does.... and that's the hill you want to die on!?
But I'm not done yet.... did you even catch what the democrats are pushing, or where you too busy frothing at the mouth because you heard the trigger word "democrat"? Yes, reducing voter suppression will help democrats more than republicans, so if you're into politics for the sole purpose of just winning political games, then by all means be against this and boycott Coke(good luck buddy).
However if you actually care about what is good for regular Americans you should absolutely support this, voter suppression is completely out of control in this country, if you don't believe me go to google right now and start comparing with other countries. No other country is doing this bullshit, and they have zero problems with voter fraud. In other countries you just grab any valid ID, usually your drivers licence or debit card, you go there and you vote, boom that's it. No registration, no sign ups, no "special unique ID" of course no one have to wait in long lines to vote. In addition in almost every other election day is a national holiday, so that people can't be prevented from voting because they had to be at work.
Voter suppression has nothing to do with election security and everything to do with power and control, just like the goddamned gerrymandering. If you can prove you are an American citizen, you are old enough and sober, there should not be a single authority in the country with the power to stop you from casting that vote.

I have one more question though, whether or not you personally care about voter suppression... imagine how many that do when even gigantic international companies like Coke and B&J are so afraid of been conceived to wrongly by the public on this. That should tell you that this is such a popular proposal among the people, that even if you personally don't agree... I would advise against picking starting a boycott over something that has this much popular support in the people.

I still need to know what this system of public safety by disbanding the police looks like. I mean, no matter what you do criminals are still going to exist. They keep talking about social workers. Are they going to send social workers into an in-progress armed robbery? I live in NH and I like to bring up the story of Michael Briggs. He was an officer that was shot and killed about 16 years ago. I believe he was on patrol and he saw Michael Addison and apparently Addison was wanted at that time for committing a robbery. Briggs had no idea that police were looking for him, and merely for the fact that they knew each other, Briggs was calling out to Addison (maybe to check in with him?) and Addison turned around and shot him. There was no struggle, no chase. All Briggs did was call his name and Addison gunned him down. Another case a few years later involved police going to a home for a drug bust, it turned into a standoff, one officer was killed and I think 4 were injured. That was a situation where the officers were blamed, not because they escalated the situation, but because they went too late in the day (so not enough light) and the investigation concluded that they should have waited for more backup. Situations can flip in a second and even people who are seemingly "safe" can turn on you in a heartbeat. There was a traffic stop in one of our more northern towns years back and the officer ended up getting shot and killed. I don't remember as many of the details on that one because I was younger when it happened. The problem is that no matter the job, there will always be human error, but with police those errors can be fatal and situations are often blink of the eye and involve snap decisions.

Let's look at the circumstances (and facts):
Sudden and sharp vote dumps for Biden in battleground states were systematically larger than other vote dumps that came into other states, making them especially crucial for swaying election outcomes in the respective states.
No sitting president in 132 years has ever gained votes between his first and second race and lost re election.
Trump won at least 11 million more votes in 2020 than in 2016, including the highest percentage of the non-white vote of any Republican candidate in 60 years (making significant gains among African-American, Latino, Jewish and even Muslim voters), yet allegedly lost.
Despite Biden allegedly receiving 15 million more votes than Obama did in his 2012 re-election, the democrats lost 13 house seats.
Biden under-performed Hillary Clinton's 2016 vote in every major metro area, yet somehow outperformed her in the major swing state cities of Milwaukee, Detroit, Atlanta and Philadelphia.
Biden also allegedly won despite having received a record low share of the Democrat primary vote; while Trump set a record for primary votes for an incumbent - 18 million primary votes, doubling the previous record, set by Bill Clinton.
Trump is one of only five incumbents to win more than 90% of the primary vote since 1912.
No incumbent who has received at least 75% of the primary vote total has ever, until 2020, lost re-election.
In Pennsylvania, only 19% of the vote additions favored Trump from November 4th through November 7th. Moreover, the integral of all vote update differences in this time range results in 578,014 votes for Biden‚Äîwith only 3,290 for Trump? ü§®

Thousands of citizens filed affidavits under oath (under penalty of perjury) asserting irregularities and illegal activities in voting places.
A Georgia polling manager testified that stacks of hundreds of "mail in" ballots that were tallied, were on perfectly flat "pristine" paper that had never been folded. (If a ballot is really mailed, it has to be folded in two places to fit in the envelope).
Georgia's Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, without legislative approval, unilaterally abrogated Georgia's statute governing the signature verification process for absentee ballots.
A sworn affidavit from mathematical analysis of the publicly available vote update data showed that: "The repetition of the many different ratios transferring simultaneously across many different precincts located many miles from each other strongly demonstrates a clear, intentional, deliberate manipulation of the votes completed via software."

Let me preface the next part by saying essentially everything the left does and advocates for is null and void by default because their intentions for doing something are always separate from what they say they're doing it for.. With that being said, our judicial system needs HUGE reform. Our policing needs HUGE reform. I have experienced first hand the corruption infested within police departments. It's bad guys, it really is. Far too often, infinitely times more than could ever be considered an anomaly, a certain personality type that should be kept as far away from having power over others as possible, are ending up with that power in a police uniform. And this whole "90% of cops are great it's just a few" is complete bullshit. There are entire departments where the culture has just been corrupted beyond belief. Now there are also MANY great police officers who are there for the right reasons and do an honorable job, but the good cops tend to congregate with the good cops and the bad ones with the bad cops, and when the bad cops get to leadership the whole department rots. But one thing that remains universal is the good cops don't stop the bad cops. Unless you have a department led by someone like Sheriff Grady Judd. If he was the rule rather than the exception things would be a lot different. Unfortunately that's not the case... I guess if there's one thing I'm trying to impart it's don't blindly take the stance of the Establishment Right or because it's in contrast with the stance of the left. You almost have to ignore the left on everything like they're the kids at the table. There is a great need for reform in policing especially hiring practices, but it's generally not for the specific reasons the left says and it's not where the left says it is. The loose canon power hungry cop isn't generally in the cities like the left portrays, people like that don't want to face the danger associated with the cities, and the cops that do work in the cities have far too much danger and stress to deal with as it is to be going around looking for crime or jamming people up. And conversely the problems in policing in the cities tends to be department policy and the bureaucratic nature of the way they deal with things. For example enforcing unconstitutional orders and acting as the muscle of a political party which in today's world is the Democrats.. We've all seen what's behind the mask of the schools because of the teachers union and the Police Unions are no different. This will probably be an unpopular opinion on your video, but I would like to play detached third party. I‚Äôm a white guy born and raised in Canada. I have been on both sides of needing the police, and running on the wrong side of them. The wrong side has always been traffic related. Speeding, not coming to a complete stop at a sign, etc. I was often pulled over just for driving at night when I was young after the cop ran my plate, even though everything was clean. On the other side, I have been the victim of armed robbery twice. I was a delivery driver. Pistol, and sawed off shotgun being the tools of choice if it matters to anyone. My point may have three points... 1). The police should use a reasonable response to the infraction. For example, don‚Äôt draw your gun on someone over a speeding ticket. 2). The police shouldn‚Äôt assume anyone doing something they consider abnormal is a hardcore criminal. I certainly never was. 3). In the case of George Floyd, even if he was as disreputable as could appear, I cannot imagine a circumstance where a cop needs to crush him down with a knee for 8 minuets. It might take one minute of that before the guy is so winded you can cuff him and shove him in the patrol car. 4). One more point than I said, but it bears mention... I don‚Äôt like the Woke movement. The issue should never be race or colour. It should be about reasonable police response to an individual‚Äôs actions or infraction. If we could get there, I think the race war would die a nice, slow, non partisan death.
